Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2009 07:30AM - edited Jun 5, 2009 11:35AM by pdaw junebug40 - Emotional wreck yes - I think that happens to all of us.  This is the 2nd time around for me.  I was diagnosed with DCIS, stage 0 in 2006 - had lumpectomy followed by 36 radiation treatments.  I stayed in denial for a while - thinking it could not happen to me until the path report came back.  I thought it was a big deal, but now since I've been diagnosed with IDC, the dr. makes that sound like nothing.  For me the second time around was worse - because I'd already convinced myself that it as C - I knew the look - I knew the procedures - I kind of just new.  However, in the back of my mind - I thought surely this is not happening to me again.  There's something to be said that "ignorance is bliss". I don't know anything about expanders.  Again, I had a lumpectomy for the second time - I have had in both breasts now.  At the time of my surgery the dr. also implanted the port above my left breast.  Am getting along fine and was glad that her normal procedure is  place the port in at the same time that she does the other surgery.  Speaking about eating before surgery- I think sometimes the medical profession assumes that we know too much.  And, we're such emotional wrecks at the time of our visits that it's hard to really comprehend anything.  My boyfriend went with me and he heard things that either I did not hear - or simply did not want to hear.  LIke you I have good times and bad times.  I have finally gotten to the point that I can talk about it without crying.  I too, am really scared about the chem.  I just want to get started so that I know how it's going to affect me.  The unknown factor is the scariest part.  We can read all these posts about everyone else's experiences, but everyone is different and will react different.  When I had my first radiation treatment, the technician said "You ARE going to be fatigued - no doubt about it.  Well fortunately for me that did not happen.  I had a very stressful position, at that time as assistant supt. of schools and was working 50+ hours most weeks the entire time I was taking radiation.  So, I learned to listen and prepare for the worst, but certainly hope for the best.  To me, it's kind of like getting a prescription filled and you get that print-out of everything that could possibly go wrong - well if you really thought that all that stuff would happen we'd never want to take any type of medicine. I think my control and my strength comes from trying to protect everyone else.  My parents are 82 years old and I'm trying real hard to put up a good front for them.  I think we all have to handle this in our own way and if you need to cry - don't try to stop it - by all means cry and DO NOT make yourself believe that crying makes you weaker.  That's what I plan to do .  Best wishes - let me hear from you!

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2009 07:20PM pdaw wrote: Hey Ladies and Tom, Has anyone seen the book "Eating Well Through Cancer". I was provided a copy when I went to the C center for my educational session.   I just today had a chance to look at it a little bit.  It was written by a medical oncologist and his wife.  It has over 200 quick recipes to ease side effects, doctor's tips, shopping lists, nutritional analysis, caregiver ideas and menus.  The table of contents has different side effects:  neutropenia, diarrhea, constipation, sore mouth or throat, and then provides recipes and menus to deal with them.  It also has recipes for high calorie-high protein meals, and snacks and light meals.  Each recipe has nutritional information per serving and most have doctor's notes  Eating Well Through Cancer  Easy Recipies & Recommendations during & after treatment Holly Clegg & Gerald Miletello, M.D. TomnDi - tips from this book for sore mouth or throat avoid tart, acidic or salty foods and drinks such as citrus fruit juices, pickled and vinegary foods, tomato-based foods, and some canned broths avoid rough textured foods, such as dry toast, granola, and raw fruits & veggies eat food that is cool or room temp.  llimit alcohol, caffeine, and toabcco - these can dry out your mouth & throat avoid spices such as chili power,cloves, curry, hot sauces, nutmeg and pepper season foods with herbs such as basil, oregano & thyme use a straw for liquids try chewing sugar-free gum or suck on sugar free candies cut food into small pieces softer and easy to swallow foods include soft, creamy foods such as cream soups, cheeses, mashed potatoes, pastas, yogurt, eggs, custards, puddings, cooked cereals, ice cream, casseroles, gravies, syrups, breakfast-type recipes, milkshakes and nutritional liquid food supplements. drink your meals with nutritious liquids soft foods: applesauce, bananas, watermelon, cottage cheese, milk shakes, or smoothies, scrambled eggs, puddings, flavored geletin, cooked cereals such as oatmeal or cream of wheat, mashed potatoes or sweet potatoes, macaroni & cheese, or mashed vegetables shoping list for sore mouth bread, butter, eggs, honey cream of wheat, grits applesauce:  fruit, no citrus (fresh, frozen canned), vegetables (fresh, frozen, canned) milk, cottage chesse, ice cream, frozen yogurt, cheese, yogurt nutritional energy drink supplements popsicles, puddings, flavored geletins, frozen whipped topping

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2009 06:32PM pdaw wrote: Poly Radiation treatments don't take that long.  It takes longer for the dr. to get you ready - so many test, markings, etc.  The machine that I was on made a clicking noise.  I counted the clicks and knew exactly how many it would take to complete the treatment.  It did its thing on one side of my body and then moved to the other side of the breast.  The last 8 treatments that I had were called "boost" and the machine was moved very close to the skin.  These did not take as long.  Yes, I had a lumpectomy in 2006 followed by 36 radiations.  That cancer was DCIS - noninvasive, stage 0, ER/PR negative so no meds could be used. I'm on prochlorperazine (10mg) for nausea.  They also gave me something in my IV.  I was not given Emend.  Nurse advised me to begin the meds night of infusion and then every 6 hours.  I felt fine on Friday (infusion on Thursday) and then on Saturday felt completely washed out.  As you said, food did not look good and was nauseous even with meds.  Did anyone else feel nauseous while on their meds?  Never threw up and felt better lying down - slept most of Saturday and Sunday.  Was able to return to work on Monday, but could not wait for the day to end.  Felt almost good as new on Tuesday.  My next treatment is July 23. Susie - I have a man friend, and we've been together almost 5 years, but I don't know that I can let him see me without a wig.  He's never even seen me with wet hair - much less no hair.  He is balding and would probably be OK with it - just not sure that I'll ever be OK.  I love your hair! Had labs done last Thursday and everything looks good.  Hope that continues because I don't want the Neulasta shot.  Dr. said that she would only give it if absolutely necessary. Gjlanders - I'm so envious of your Paris trip and hope that you feel great.  This is a place that man friend and I have talked about going.  We went to London for Christmas in 2007. Mamaq - My blood count was 2.4 and I understand that number is low.  However, the nurse said that they use an equation of several numbers and items in the blood.  That total is OK as long as it's at least 1,000 and mine was 1800+.  Maybe your center does the same thing as mine.  I was told that mine should be coming up this week.  Carolyn & Polly - Was your second AC a lot worse than the first?  Are you going every 3 weeks x 4 and then 12 weeks of taxol? Like several of you, food tastes different or no taste at all.  I'm experimenting with some different colas.  I drank a Diet Sun Drop that tasted really good this weekend.  I could actually taste the lemon-line flavor. Do any of you have strange sensations to cold drinks?  It feels like I can feel the liquid going all the way down my throat.  And my toothpaste seems to make my mouth tingle also. Carolyn - I had a couple days over the weekend where my eyes watered - seems to be better now. I went to the LGFB class this afternoon.  Mine was all about make-up - no wigs were shared.  And, I was the only person who showed up for the class.  In some respects that was good, cause I got individualized treatment.  The bag of make-up is very nice.  I plan to visit a cancer center in a nearby town tomorrow or Wednesday and see what they have in their "wig room".

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 05:24PM pdaw wrote: Engtchr - Thanks for sharing your positive experience with  Lidocaine  - it's my new best friend.  For those who don't know it's a prescription numbing creme.  I was instructed to rub it on about 30 minutes prior to my appointment.  I was really nervous after bad experience with CT and bone scan needles this week. I have really poor veins.  Like you - I never even felt a prick of the needle.  I went to cancer center first where they cleaned and checked the port.  Then I went to the hospital for my MUGA scan.   The cancer center gave the hospital permission to use the port.   I have a power port, and found out that I'm the first patient at my cancer center and the hospital to ever have one of these "new fangled" things.  In fact, I took my brochure with me and my medical oncologist made copies of it.  When it was first put in, I was told that it could be used for almost everything.  Then when I went in for the CT scan, I was told they could not use it cause the "stuff" that goes in is thick and must go in quickly, which could not be accomplished through a port.   Now today, for the MUGA, they too, wanted a copy of my brochure.  And, it seems it could have been used for the CT, but the hospital does not even have a protocol for using it.  I'm not assertive, but I'm learning that I need to ask questions and maybe be more forceful.  In a nice way - I told them today that if they could not figure it all out prior to another CT scan, that I would return to the hospital where the port was put in and have the scan there. TomniDi - if Diane does not like the prick - maybe she can ask for a prescription for this.  I'm telling you it was wonderful!   Girls - I got my wig today.  The stylist at the salon was wonderful!  If you get a wig from ACS, don't be disappointed when you first get it -  take it to your stylist and let her work with it. I really was not super happy when we finally got a color that matched by hair - but the stylist cut it the way I wear my hair and I must say that I am pleasantly surprised.  My hair is fine - have never had a "crowning glory" but it's mine and I would love to keep it. Also, something else I learned today.  I wear my hair parted on the side and since it fine, the part, or my scalp is very distinct.  You can purchase wigs with an insert on the top that looks like your scalp!  I really think my "new hair" looks fairly natural - hope others think so as well.  I think I'll put it on one night this weekend and see what my man friend says.  I also purchased the shampoo, hair spray and a brush for maintenance.  have a great weekend -

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 06:01PM - edited Jun 29, 2009 06:04PM by pdaw Polly - thanks for the encouragement - just came back from Walgreens to pick up meds - Magic Mouthwash and prochloroerazine for nausea and vomiting.  And yet, another set of possible side effects to become familiar with.  I'm approaching the side effects, like I do with any prescription - it's unlikely but you need to know the what ifs.  I'm really trying to remain positive and you have helped.  It will be interesting to see if food turns my stomach - it seems that when I'm stressed I tend to eat more - not less.  And who would I see in Walgreens - but a young girl - I would guess in her 20's - with a baseball cap on and I could tell she was bald.  I just wanted to go up to her and hug her and say I know - or will know how you feel real soon. I also know how you feel about working.  Part of me would just like to hiberate in my house until all of this is over.  But I work with a great group of folks -  there are about 70 of us all together, but only about 9 in my administrative office.  And, we work with children and adults with developmental disabilities so they are so tuned in to HIPPA laws, and working with people who are going through difficult times - and who look different. They have to this point been extremely concerned and helpful.  My boss, has said "do whatever you need to do - but the first thing you do is to take care of yourself."  I am very lucky to have such a supportive group to work with. As for me with the hair - my hair has fine texture - never had gorgeous hair - but it's mine and I'd love to keep it.  When I went wig shopping at the salon, everything at first looked fake.  The main thing, I think was that I've always parted my hair and the wigs did not really have a part in them.  When I mentioned that, she said look at this one.  The wig actually has a piece sewn into the top which made a very natural looking part.  It was expensive, but I had a $200 voucher from a foundation here to help pay for it.  I'm trying it on each night to try to get used to looking at myself in it.  The hairdresser put it on me and styled it similar to my current hairstyle - just not as short as what I'm doing now.   Take care and try to stay focused on the future and the end of treatment!  Remember to take care of yourself first - listen to your body.

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2009 07:21PM - edited Jun 24, 2009 07:27PM by pdaw I had my "education" class today.  Met with nutritionist, insurance nurse and chemo nurse.  More information overload.  However, lots of good info - step by step printed sheets for different side effects.  They also gave me a cookbook that looks great - it had different side effects listed and different foods, ideas and recipes to use. Has anyone heard of Magic Mouthwash.  It's a prescription - was told to use this if I get mouth sores.  You swish it around and then swallow it 30 minutes before meals and at bedtime.  Nurse said that the sores can also go down your throat - reason for swallowing.  Other ideas on my little fact sheet for mouth sores: What to eat and drink. Use a straw to drink liquid and take small bites and chew food completely Soften food with milk, broth, gravy, juice, yogurt, butter, jelly or other liquid if needed.  Use a blender to mash or blend fruits and vegies. If cold feels good, suck on ice chips.  Personally, the ice cream sounds better to me. Drink 8-10 large glasses of caffeine-free liquid each day.  Keep a water bottle with you always Try to eat at times of day when mouth pain is less intense. Swish and gargle with warm water to moisten mouth before eating. For thick saliva, try sipping 100% papaya juice which contains natural substances that can thin saliva Try high-calorie liquids and semi-soft foods,such as fruit smoothies or shakes, warm soup, pasta, etc. avoid spicy, salty or citrus foods that can irritate avoid tobacco and alcoholic beverages How to treat: start using the magic mouthwash rinse with warm saline solution mouth rinses keep mouth and lips moist by using lip balm brush teeth with a soft toothbrush or toothette after each meal. Betina - good luck tomorrow - does this mean that after tomorrow you are 1/2 through? I was a little down today after my visit.  Dr. said that I could probably continue to work on the 4 treatment - every 3 weeks schedule; however nurse said today that I would  see a huge difference with fatigue with the 3 and 4th treatment.  I'm going to remember that everyone is different and try to keep a positive attitude.  If I have to take a leave of absence - that's what I'll do to fight this thing!!!  Take care everyone!

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 06:37AM - edited Jun 29, 2009 06:39AM by pdaw White 929 - I also have a similar diagnosis.  I'm IDC, 2 cm, Stage IIa, Grade 3, Triple N.  I will also begin my treatment on Thursday - so best of luck to you!  I understand the feelings.  I wish someone could say exactly what's going to happen.  I have followed closely all of these posts.  I tried to imagine myself with no hair.  I'm trying to stay positive about everything and some days are better than others.  This site is a wonderful friend, counselor and doctor, so stick with it. No one can say, "I know how you feel" if they have not been through this.  And that's the beauty of this wonderful site - everyone has or is going through exactly what we are going through.  If you have read everything on "before, after and during chemo" make sure that you do.  There's a wonderful list of items to have on hand - everything from food to hygiene items.  I have my basket of things ready.  Can't tell you how many trips to WalMart I've made. Polly - Radiation was not bad at all for me.  Technician told me at the first visit that I would be fatigued, but that did not happen.  I was working a very stressful job with school district 50+ hours per week.  I left at 4:00 for a treatment and returned back to work most of the time.  My skin tolerated the treatment very well.  It's a little darker where they radiated.  The last 8 treatments, for me, were called boost treatments and they move the machine much closer to the skin and place it right above the incision.  Where my incision is remains numb and will probably always be that way.  It's a piece of cake compared to chemo! Renee - Video was wonderful! Susie & Rinna - Sorry to hear about things getting harder for you.  I wonder if that's what is in store for me since I'm on the same treatment as you.  Someone at work told me that they heard breast cancer treatment was the hardest any patient has to go through. Like most of you, I'm loosing a lot of hair.  I wash it every day - dry it - and then get the vacuum cleaner out.  Started wearing my "other hair" to work on Monday. Today, I'm home from work.  White blood count is low and I've kind of put myself into seclusion.  Well, I really wanted to go to work but dear man friend thought otherwise and since he's taking care of things, I decided to listen to him. Rinna & Greytmon - I'm not a coffee drinker but love tea - especially McDonald's tea.  But it's not good anymore, so I've been experimenting with some other drinks - Diet Rite Cola and Diet SunDrop are two that seem to taste good to me.  Tea seems to be getting better but there's another treatment around the corner. cs34 - What is Acidophilus (probiotic) - were did you get it? U32374 - It the Activia drink like Activia yogurt?  Best wishes today on your treatment. I too had a pity party this week.  My former next-door neighbor lost her daughter to Cervical cancer on Wednesday.  I lost a friend to BC this week.  One of my best friends is tending to her husband, who was recently diagnosed with a malignant brain tumor.  My hair began falling out on Tuesday and my white blood count was way.....down yesterday.  So, I've placed myself in isolation and am home today.  Fortunately, my boss is allowing me to do some work from home on days when I don't need to be around people.   You all know that some days/weeks it takes more energy to keep a positive attitude.  This was one of mine.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2009 07:02PM - edited Nov 19, 2009 07:05PM by pdaw Rinna - good luck with the rads.  I took 36 rads in 06 when I had DCIS.  Most of the time it took longer to get undressed and ready to get on the table - than it actually took for the treatment.  Does your machine have a clicking noise and does it move from side to side.  Mine did - and I counted the clicks so that I knew exactly when the machine was going to move to the other side and when it would finish.  Just a little mind game for me.  At the end I had 8 boosts - this is when they move the machine much closer to the skin and right on top of the incision.  Some of you have heard my rads story - but let me tell you again if it will reassure anyone  For those of you worrying about rads = please do NOT!  Believe me rads is a piece of cake compared to what all of you have already gone through.  I remember the first day of my '06 rads, when the technician said " you are going to be fatigued - you probably will not work.  I had a very stressful job as assistant superintendent in a school district - and the board of ed. decided that year that they were going to take our county commissioners to court.  So, my 45-50hr. a week job became one in which I worked from 7:30 a.m. to 10or 11p.m. each night for several weeks.  I would leave my office at 4:00 - drive 30 miles (because at that time my cancer center in my town was not doing rads) - take a treatment - and then go back to work. Now, this might not be the case this time - because I did have one dr. say that sometimes after chemo the fatigue is a little worse.  However, that certainly may not be the rads - but simply chemo left in the body.  Anyway, again, please be assured that it's not bad.  It's very annoying to have to go EVERY DAY! As for me - had #6 of  Taxol today! If you pray, please add my best friend's husband.  He has an inoperable Stage IV brain tumor and is not doing well. Pam

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 07:24PM - edited Jun 9, 2009 07:28PM by pdaw junebug - How are you feeling?  How brave you are to go ahead with shaving your head.  I had that discussion with my man friend last night and he said you really ought to cut your hair real short and go ahead and begin wearing the wig.  I really don't have a wig yet, but have picked out several from the internet that I like.  The salon that I am being referred to has a great website. I had not thought about the wig being itchy - the only thing I've heard others say is that they can be hot.   I know how you feel about talking about it.  Nothing you are feeling is strange - we all have to deal with it in our own way. I just got off the phone with a friend and I realized that I could talk to her without breaking down.  I return to surgeon tomorrow for follow up from last week's surgery and pathology report.  Hopefully, I'll have good clean margins and not have to return to surgery.  She also placed a port in last week and I'm ready for her to remove this bandage so I can see what the skin looks like.  Jewlls - hang in there and know that all of us will be thinking about and praying for your recovery.  I have learned so much from others here on these discussion boards.  As you read through these posts, you will probably think of some questions to ask your Onc.  I know that I'll have some as soon as I find out what chemo treatment I will actually be on.  I really did not know there were different kinds until I started reading this discussion board.  Like you, I'm happy that the tumor has been removed.  Now, I'm anxious about what the path report says about the lymph nodes.  Happy birthday yesterday! Steinunn - it appears from other posts that poor sleep is a major SE with AC.  Good luck with your decision on the wig.  I hope to look within the next week for one.  I don't think I can wait until it starts to fall out.  A friend from church told me that she was out of town when she noticed her hair falling out.  She said that she put the car window down, stuck her head out and ran her fingers through her hair and it just came out in bunches.  Her husband said "what are you doing"  Her response:  I'm giving the birds my hair to build a nest with.  She was very brave - did not like her wig because it was hot.  She wore baseball hats most of the time.  She actually had a pink baseball cap from Baldhead Island that her daughter-in-law gave her as a gift.  I'm happy for you that your treatment went well.  Let's hope that your feelings with the wig will go as well.  Don't wait too long.  I've heard too many people say that they began loosing their hair around day 14-15.  If you'd like the website of the salon that I'm using let me know.  They have a great selection. zuzee - So we can drink wine on chemo - that's great news!!  I agree with you and will probably at least cut my hair very, very short prior to it falling out.  That's one thing that I can control.  Regarding the radiation - I had DCIS in 2006 and the 1st thing the technician said to me was count on being fatigued.  Well, that did not happen to me - I worked every day  - and some weeks 50+ hours per week because we had something very serious happening at work.  My advice - at least to myself is - listen to everything and wait to see what happens with your body.  Everyone is different - as so very evidenced by these posts.  Keep that positive attitude - I believe that's a big part of our battle! Betinna - so happy to hear that 1st treatment went well for you.  That gives the rest of us great hope for our first treatment! rinna - I guess I just assumed no alcohol - good to hear that zuzee could still have a little glass of wine. Pap - Like you, I'm very concerned about loosing eyelashes, 'cause I've always had nice, long lashes.  But you know what, I think I can get those at WalMart!  Like you, I'll try real hard to think of the chem and radiation as a "friend".  I think it's a great way to approach it - once you get over the initial diagnosis shock. Greytmom - I have not startment my treatments yet - but feel like I've had chemo brain every since the diagnosis!  Everyone have a great night and for those of you having treatments tomorrow - best wishes to you!

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 03:40PM pdaw wrote: Hey ladies This web site will tell you a little about Look Good, Feel Better Program - this is the cancer center in my hometown. http://www.marionlshepardcancercenter.org/lookgoodfeelbetter.htm Check on a program where you plan to have your treatments.  At my center, if the website is correct, the program is held every month.  I plan to get enrolled in the July session since I've already missed the June session.  This is where I'll have my treatments.  Fortunately for me it's just a couple blocks from my house.   I went back to surgeon yesterday.  Thank God for some good news - the beast is not in my lymph nodes.  My stats:  2.4 cm (grew from 1.9 to 2.4 in about 10 days), Stage 2A, Grade 3, 0 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- I'm seeing my medical oncologist tomorrow at 4:00.  My surgeon told me yesterday that I could still be a couple weeks or more from starting treatment - depending on how I'm healing.  And, she said that I'm healing great!  The way she explained it is that the cells that are now being used to heal from my surgery are the same cells that the chemo will destroy.  So, not a good thing to begin too early.  Though I hate to start, I feel that my mind is ready to begin.  Like all of you, I don't want to loose my hair - BUT I do want to get rid of any possible cancer cells, that could eventually take my life.  Someone else in an earlier post, either here or on another discussion group said it's best to try to think of the treatment "as a friend and not a foe" - cause that's what's going to get rid of our problems.  I'm still working on the friend part.  Like many of you it's all hard to understand and I've gone through the same thing, but we are women - strong women - who are leaning on each other AND we're all going to fight this thing with everything we have.  Thanks for letting me join the June group.  I still may make it before the end of June.   Anybody and Everybody.....how long have you had to wait between surgery and 1st treatment?  I'm a planner and the waiting and the unknown is so.....difficult for me.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2009 10:16PM pdaw wrote: backagain - I feel your pain.  I was diagnosed with DCIS in 2006 (noninvasive, stage 0) lumpectomy followed by 36 rads.  Hope treatment went well for you today. I too have handed all of this over to a higher being - it's way too big for me to handle by myself. I receive some good pre-information from my cancer center.  They gave me a whole bag of stuff including information sheets on different things that could happen - constipation, diarrhea, low blood count, etc.  On each sheet it tells you how you will feel if this is happening - what to eat - what to take and when to call them back.  Also received a cookbook - "Eating well with Cancer".  It's really good and has recipes and shopping lists for all the Side Effects.  If anyone is interested, I'll post more info regarding the book. One thing I've learned is to always take something to do - even for regular check-ups.  My dr. office seems to pride themselves on keeping appointments timely, but occasionally something goes wrong.  I'm planning to keep a small paperback in my purse all the time.  Joni - are you sure that what you see is swelling.  I had my put in June 1 during my lumpectomy surgery and I have a bump where it's located. Gillyone - I had a CT, bone scan and MUGA also.  I have no lymph node involvement - but was told that it was possible that one microscopic cancer cell could have still slipped through the nodes.  I started my treatment July 2 - A/C every 3 wks. x 4 and then Taxol, weekly x 12, followed by radiation.  I began listening to the june threat.  This is the place to learn a lot from each other.  Keep the faith! Good luck to all having their first treatment this week! Pam

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 07:16PM pdaw wrote: Joni1 - I took ice and flavored water with me in a large insulated cup; however, ice chips, drinks, water, chips, cookies and nice warm blankets were all available in my chemo bay.  Also, nice reclining chairs and TV at each chair.  I'll probably take my large insulated cup with me again, then I don't have to ask for ice chips if I give out.  They really try to make patients feel as comfortable as possible.  I'm on several vitamins and a couple of prescriptions, and took everything as normal - especially the BP meds as this entire ordeal has made BP rise.  I was also advised to eat a light supper night before so I made chicken and rice soup and made enough to have for a couple of meals in case I did not feel like cooking. I think the food idea is nice for your family -did not go back to see if you have children at home.  My dear man friend is very particular about his food - used to be a total vegetarian.  Does not eat beef or pork.  So we eat a lot of poultry, seafood and pasta.  I have learned to cook for him - just a matter of using the proper sugar, flour etc.  Don't know how much cooking I could have done on day 3 and 4.  I took the compazine for nausea and pretty much slept those 2 days away.  I had cooked up soup, meatloaf, pasta salad and some other items for us to eat and we made out fine.  I returned to work on Monday - though was glad to see the clock strike 4:00. O2bhealthy - I purchased the Biotene and then my oncologist gave me a prescription for something called "magic mouthwash".  You swish it around 30 minutes prior to eating and then are supposed to swallow it.  - have not been able to swallow it yet - it's not that the taste is awful but it's like swallowing your mouthwash and you know you're not supposed to do that - guess it a mind game.  I think what I had was an inflamed tastebud - better now since using the mouthwash 4x a day.  I was having trouble with my Crest Prohealth toothpaste tingling a bit much so I purchased the Biotene toothpaste and it's great! Lorrijo 1993 - My dr. recommended Sennacot-S for constipation and it works well - has a stool softener which also helps.  They told me to take something if I had problems after 3 days.  This time, I'll probably take something sooner, cause I know what's going to happen.  I'm normally pretty regular, so I know when my body is doing something crazy.  The C went away after about a week. Elizabeth - what a beautiful story you have to share.  Wanda - I agree the lidocaine is wonderful!!!! Gil - My dressing was a type of water-proof bandage that stayed on over a week until I went back for my checkup and then dr. removed it.  I was told it was OK to take a shower after 48 hours - just don't let water pound on the bandages. Loving life today - I love OJ but went cold turkey after the first treatment and started drinking Cranberry/Apple or Cranberry/Grape juice.  It's good for you cause it does not have the acid that OJ has. Linda Sue - Did they give you something for nausea in your IV prior to infusion?  I got that, and also began taking meds that evening.  Felt nothing until Saturday (infusion on Thursday)  Sorry for the long post - trying to catch on my reading

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2009 06:27PM - edited Aug 5, 2009 06:28PM by pdaw Tara - what kind of treatment are you scheduled to take?  Don't worry about the hair just yet.  I'm on AC (adrimicin and cytoxin) every 3 weeks.  My hair began shedding more than usual on day 13.  it appears that most of us notice something around day 14.  My first treatment was july 2 and I still have some hair.  Yes, I'm wearing a wig, cause it's very thin especially on top - but when I wear a baseball cap there's still hair (though thin) peaking out from under the cap.  You have to choose the right decision for you.  For me, I thought that I could shave my head - but could not bring myself to do that.  My hair is fine anyway.  Now, I'm glad I did not because of what hair I still have.  Now, the rest might fall out within the next few days, but I'm only seeing a little bit each morning now when I wash it.  I would advise you to go ahead and get a wig if that's what you plan to do, so that you will have time to have it styled and have it when you need it.  If you just joined us for the first time, make sure you get your free wrap.  If you don't know what I'm talking about let us know.  If you have time to read all of this, you can find great tips for getting through this from the other posts.  But, most of all you will be grateful for the support from this group of strong, loving, praying women!  I have worked every day, except for treatment days and one other day when white blood count was low.  I actually went back to work after the last treatment and finished out my day.  My office is about 10 minutes from my cancer center.  I sure would not plan to work the first day because it's so stressful physically and emotionally.  I felt fine - just tired.  Like Connie, folks at my office are amazed that I'm able to work.  One of my doctors - advised me to not think too far ahead.  That works for me.  Another said think about looking forward to holidays - by Labor Day I'll be finished with AC and by Thanksgiving I'll be through with Taxol.  Like Connie also, I've had to deal with very few side effects.  Everyone is different and that's the disturbing thing - cause you don't know how it's going to affect you until you have that first treatment.  I slept really good the night of the first one - just to know it was behind me. Wanda - good luck on 2nd AC Hoping for a cure -  my wrap was beautiful - but the note, signed by everyone in Laurie's office made me cry also!  Pam

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 10:21PM - edited Oct 26, 2009 10:23PM by pdaw Connie - my medical oncologist and my B surgeon both said that if I chose to have a mastectomy that I would not do the radiation.  However, my sentinal node was negative so I don't know if that makes a difference.  The radiation can damage the skin so I guess that can make the reconstruction more difficult.  I would go through it if the drs said that it was needed.  I had a lumpectomy in left breast in 2006 and one in right breast in June 09.  I understand how you feel about removing the good breast.  With my history and the fact that my BRAC1 test came back with inconclusive, I have asked about having double mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.  I talked with oncologist and surgeon this week and they have consulted with each other and think my choice is a good one considering my history.  I understand that this does not preclude me from getting cancer somewhere else in the future.  But isn't that something that everyone deals with who has any type of cancer.  And, like you, my dr. has recommended removal of ovaries.  Jayne - I'm in the same shape as you.  I've missed taxol treatments the past 2 weeks because of low blood counts.  I was close last week and dr. is sure, I'll be able to take treatment this week.  She does not want me to miss any more - so on Friday, Monday and Tuesday, I'll begin neupogen (not sure about spelling) injections.  My toes are numb from the taxol and I really think that I'm getting the Avastin (from the chemical trial that I'm on).  I have several of the SE that come from Avastin.  Congrats to all who have finished chemo!! Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2009 10:12PM - edited Aug 5, 2009 10:12PM by pdaw Ladies - please keep Edie (quarter405) in your prayers.  She is going through a tough time with treatment #2.  Also, had a difficult time with treatment 1. Kathy - like you my employer has been most gracious in asking if I need time off and is going to let me use the intermittent FMLA as needed.  I am on Adramyacin and have gotten along fine - you are absolutely correct - everyone is so different.  That's what makes that first treatment so scary! Lori - can't wait to visit K-mart.  Have not found any really cute hats anywhere else.  niknak0320 -   Personally, I've had the constipation, the instructions from my dr. if it should occur are:  What not to drink: milk, coffee or alcohol What not to eat: fried, fatty, greasy, spicy foods, raw fruits and vegies, beans, popcorn, nuts high fiber or bran cereals What to drink: 8-10 large glasses of non-caffeinated fluid a day (sounds weird, but guess that's to keep you from getting dehydrated) drink a little at a time, as often as you can What to eat: eat several small meals follow BRAT diet - bananas, rice, applesauce, toast Instructions from my dr on how to treat: 2 caplets (4mg) of Imodium A-D at the first sign of diarrhea, and then take 1 caplet (2 mg) after each subsequent stool. If this does not control, then increase Imodium A-D to 1 caplet (2mg) every 2 hours Continue taking the Imodium until you have no diarhea for 12 hours Then instructions say, if after following the above and still have 4 or more BM then call the nurse. Also call nurse, if you have bloody stools, nausea and/or vomiting with the diarrhea, or fever. Hope this helps. Pam

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 07:51PM pdaw wrote: Wanda - My port was placed at the time of my surgery.  My dr. said she believes in doing it all at one time if possible.  I did feel the port for a couple of weeks, particularly if I was lying on that side.  I think some of that was probably the healing process and the fact that psychologically there was a foreign object in my body.  My first treatment was July 2.  You will love the port.  My dr. gave me lidocaine (numbing creme) and I never even felt a prick of the needle.  They will first check out your port by running saline solution through it.  This is something they will do each treatment.  And, if you are getting more than one kind of chemo they will run the saline between solutions. And again at the end.  At least, this was my experience.  I have a friend who does not use the creme and says she feel nothing because they pull the skin tight and then use the needle.  You are on the same med as me.  I got along fine day 1 and 2 and then started to feel fatigued on 3 & 4. I slept a lot and ate very little but don't know how much of that was from the nauseous meds I was taking.  I want to try to continue working, so I scheduled my treatment on Thursday.  By Monday, I went back to work, but was ready for "quittin' time".  By Tuesday and Wednesday - good as new!  Good luck! Prv - my treatment plan is the same as yours.  Read above for how I got along with first treatment.  I've had a few other things to happen since that first weekend.  My mouth and throat are more sensitive to cold and heat.  I have what appears to be an inflamed taste bud on the end of my tongue.  However, I had this once before years ago, so it may have nothing at all to do with treatment.  I've also had a couple of small places on my lip. - just little red spots  I've never had a fever blister and anyway it does not look like one.  I'll ask about these little annoyances when I go for bloodwork tomorrow.  I agreed to the clinical trial, because my doctor thought that I should.  She is not only my dr. but also my friend and I'll do whatever she tells me to do.  And, she is known to be one of the top 5 oncologists in the United States.  I also had some constipation for a couple of days but used the suggested over the counter Sennacot-S and it worked fine.  Hope that makes you feel better about the trial.  The side effects from this don't really worry me any more than those of the other drugs.  And, there's a chance you won't be on it anyway.  The first time is the worst cause the A takes 30 minutes - the C takes 30 minutes and the clinical trial of Avastin takes 90 minutes.  Next week my Avastin will be 60 minutes and the next time and all future times will be 30 minutes.

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2009 07:48PM pdaw wrote: Connie - I'm disappointed to hear of loosing eyelashes and brows during Taxol.  I was told that "head hair" would start to grow back, so naturally assumed that I would not loose any more hair anywhere.  I will probably start Taxol in October - every week for 12 weeks.  I have my last AC on Sept. 3 and will have a 3-week break before starting Taxol.  I was told Taxol is a piece of cake after AC.  I take B6 everyday normally so hopefully that will help.  I'm happy that you felt great after #4.  Number 3 has been harder on me. LindaSue - you and your family are in my prayers.  Dr. added the Emmend in IV form to my 2nd treatment and it really helped.  She gave me that + an Emmend pill for the next 2 nights after treatment #3. Gillyone - I try to remember take a Sennacot each night or in the morning for about a week after treatment - helps a lot.  Was also told today that I could add some Mirilax if I needed it.  Nurse said that it has no taste so you can mix it with anything.  Take care everyone! Pam
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 03:13PM - edited Aug 22, 2009 03:13PM by pdaw Gil - I was told the same thing on the synthetic wig.  I purchased the recommended shampoo and hair spray.  You don't use much so the product should last a long time.  Unlike Karen, I was also told not to use any heat on mine - but if needed some lift use a foam roller, spray with the hair spray and brush out when dry.  Sometimes, I do spray my bangs at night and brush out in the morning. niknak - I admire you young mothers having to go through this terrible disease and treatment.  Hope your husband becomes more understanding as time goes on.  Ask  him to take your kids out to McDonald's or somewhere to play to just give you a break once in a while.  You have to take care of yourself! Pam
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2009 07:31PM pdaw wrote: jewlls - I would probably be nervous also if I were awake.  Fortunately for me, surgeon placed the port when she performed my lumpectomy.  The good thing is that you will absolutely love the port!  I do not have good veins and the port has been wonderful!  Maybe they will give you some valium or ask them to cover your face.  I had lasik eye surgery several years ago, and of course, you have to be awake for that.  Dr. gave me valium and covered my face with steril cloth.  Good luck! Pam

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 08:15PM - edited Sep 28, 2009 08:17PM by pdaw Connie - After two cancers - one in both breasts, I'm thinking strongly about double mast.  My BRACA test did not come out negative or positive - inconclusive but with my history Dr. is leaning towards surgery.  Final decision is up to me - I just don't want to go through this again.   Both my surgeon and my medical oncologist say no rads, if I'm going to proceed with surgery.  I believe it has something to do with the effects on the skin if you plan to have reconstruction.  I begin taxol on Thursday - was supposed to begin last week, but blood count was down, mouth was sore, had low great fever and foot was infected from one fire ant sting. Was placed on an antiobiotic which totally messed with my gut!  Now I'm on something to help with that. Pam

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 02:24PM pdaw wrote: Congrats Janye and Gilly Blood count up on Thursday so I had treatment.  Had my first neupogen shot on Friday - have another on Monday and Tuesday.  Gil - my taste issues seem to be worse with taxol - but maybe it's because I'm on a weekly dose.  With AC by the second week taste seemed to get better - just in time for another treatment.  Guess I'll miss all the "good tastes" of the holiday.  But I have not lost weight - keep looking for something that tastes really good.  Happy birthday!!  josybee - I also have the tingling in my toes - fingers OK for now.  Have a great weekend!! Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2010 02:47PM pdaw wrote: Best wishes to everyone for a HEALTHY 2010!  I completed my last taxol on Dec. 22 (Merry Christmas to me!).  I have numbness in feet and a little in hands.  I too am battling the dry skin patches - have them on hands, face, and my sides.  Dr. told me on Wednesday to try 1% hydrocortesone.  Also told me to get either I think "udder balm" lotion or Eucerni.  I found the Eucerni and have been using it everyday - I use at night and then put gloves on.  Have had trouble with some skin around thumbs actually splitting and getting very sore - but am happy that the fingernails stayed on - very, very short, but hanging on.   It was hard to do Christmas  cooking and not be able to taste anything - looking forward to getting the taste buds back.   I'll see my PS and BC surgeons mid January in preparation for double Mast. possibly in February.  I've been through BC two times and just don't want to deal with it again.  I'm still don't understand, and I guess drs don't either why the stats say that Mast. vs. lumpectomy does not change the prognosis.  But I'm TN and I understand that it can come back somewhere else - but can't that happen to anyone with any type of cancer. Take care everyone and thanks for all the support each of you has shown to me in 2009!!  Love and hugs!!!! Pam

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2011 04:37PM pdaw wrote: Hey Nikki, Tell me about fat grafting.  About me:  I was diagnosed in May 2009 with IDC - had lumpectomy June 1.  Then in July 09, began AC chemo for 4 weeks, every 3 weeks, - then 12 weeks of taxol.  In addition, I was on the Avastin clinical trial and was indeed getting the "stuff".  My BRACA test came back inconclusive.  I also had DCIS in other breast in 2006, which involved a lumpectomy and 36 rounds of radiation.   After having 2 kinds of BC and in both breasts, I made a command decision to have a bilateral mast. which happened in Feb. 2010 followed by immediate latismus dorsi reconstruction.  There was some research that said that Avastin chemo might cause healing problems - and with me it did.  I was using creams and bandages until May of last year. My PS wanted me to wait a year so I just had my nipples done March 4.  Anyway, he took some fat from my stomach and did lipo to my breasts to take care of some rippling that was occurring with the implants.  He said that this had nothing to do with his part of the surgery but had something to do with the way the mastectomy was done.  I was wondering if what I had done is what you are calling fat grafting.  It felt really nice at first, but I've realized since the swelling has gone down that I still feel some rippling.  My PS was very pleased with how everything looked - but I still had some swelling at that point.  I see him again in a couple of weeks Is the rippling something that I'm going to have to accept or will.  Why did you have to have additional grafts?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 10:52PM - edited May 7, 2011 10:54PM by pdaw HeidiToo, I understand what you mean about the survivor thing.  I asked my dr. last year - when are you a survivor and she said from day 1.  Although, I still have a hard time saying that I'm a survivor.  I'm not a negative person at all and have kept a good mental outlook throughout the experience - but it seems I still feel like a patient.  When I was diagnosed in 2006, with  DCIS, my dr. at that time acted like it was nothing - and nothing at all to worry about returning - you know stage 0 and all.  And then it came back in 2009 different breast and IDC this time.  Anyway, our thoughts and prayers go up to Lisa and her family.  Lisa - who has been a source of strength for so many of us.  Lisa - who was so encouraging and who started the July 2009 thread.  Our Lisa - who kept the thread going that has weaved all of us together as sisters in a way that we none wanted to experience.  Prayers also to each of you as we all feel this pain. I know that personally for me - it going to set me back - into a reality that I don't want to be in.  I pray each night for everyone on this site - not by name - but "all the ladies on the BC site.
